La Gauloise Christmas est une véritable bière de Noël, qui ne rentre pas dans la catégorie des bières exceptionnelles, mais qui sait égayer une froide soirée dhiver. Véritable bière de Noël car elle répond aux codes qui, à mon sens, doivent être respectées pour ce style : une présence suave et chaleureuse en bouche qui demande pour le dernier point un degré minimum dalcool (8 % Abv apparaît être un seuil en dessous duquel il devient plus compliqué dobtenir cette sensation de chaleur procurée par lalcool), et une recette intégrant des épices ou autres ingrédients permettant à des arômes corsés de sexprimer. Force est de constater que les bières brunes permettent plus facilement de respecter ces critères afin dobtenir une boisson festive. Notre Gauloise Christmas confirme cette règle avec une robe brune limpide (EBC de 72) surmontée dune mousse beige et crémeuse, abondante, de 5 cm dépaisseur mais retombant par la suite. Les épices présents dans la recette : Coriandre et réglisse. Le nez est classique dune double avec des arômes de céréales, pruneaux, café avec néanmoins une touche de coriandre et de girofle. Lattaque est corsée, sur les céréales, lorange et la girofle : excellente entrée en matière ! Lamertume qui sen suit est dintensité moyenne (EBU 22) mais poussée par un alcool bien présent. Les arômes de pruneaux sont les plus prégnants avec un arrière bouche déclinant des notes de cerises et une pointe chocolatée. La densité de larrière bouche manque toutefois légèrement dintensité pour une bière de Noël. Léquilibre est cependant globalement bien trouvée. Le final est quant à lui relativement décevant, présentant des notes épicées mais dune intensité et dune longueur insuffisante. Il manque donc quelques guirlandes au sapin pour un Noël inoubliable, mais nous sommes déjà dans lambiance des fêtes!

0.33l bottle. Brownis dark red body, light brown foam. Aroma of caramel, candi sugar, sour cherry with some cloves. Taste of caramel, brown sugar, sour cherry and chocolate. Quite sweet beer with creamy texture. I like it.

incredibile birra Natalizia, buona e sorprendente. Invecchiata due anni dopo la naturale scadenza, presenta splendide caratteristiche. Già un naso di buona carica, ma poco vario. Avverto liquirizia, rum, castagne e prugne ed un tocco finale di resina. In bocca ha una buona carbonatazione, è non troppo piena al palato ma nemmeno acquosa, in piena armonia con lo stile. Bella birra, ne ho unaltra che vorrei fare invecchiare ancora. La dolcezza di Castagne iniziali si perde nella complessità del sapore di rum e curaçao, kliquirizia ed il finale lievemente citrico. Buona birra, mi è piaciuta molto.

Une bière de Noël  Toujours une grande attente  et une inquiétude sur le résultat 
Bref, on sait que lon a devant soi une bière spéciale, mais sera-ce dans le bon sens ?
Ici, je dirais : mi-figue, mi-raisin... Ce qui est déjà difficile pour la bière, mais on va 
essayer de sexpliquer 
Affichée à 8,1 % abv, cest bien, mais on ne va pas crier pour une Christmas !
Bouchonnée de liège, et bouchon numéroté : très bien.
Etiquette au père Noël on ne peut plus classique : bof !
Couleur brun foncé, quasi noir, même en transparence : bien pour le genre.
Clarté nette : bien
Bulles fines à moyennes, très nombreuses : très bien.
Mousse beige, fine, très crémeuse, qui vient caler à 5 ou 6 mm : très bien.
Arômes de café, chocolat noir, pruneau et une pointe de girofle : sympa.
Texture assez structurée : on aurait préférer soyeuse (pour le genre).
1ère bouche avec une nuance danis étoilé mise en avant, assez fine, sur une saveur café.
Arrière-bouche assez fraîche (trop?) pour une Christmas, mais bien présente.
2ème bouche avec des épluchures de pomme de terre (on ne comprend pas ), avec de la
menthe et de lanis très délicat.
3ème bouche toujours fraîche, mais avec sa touche exotique.
Arrière-bouche bien faite et assez longue.
La longueur par contre napporte pas beaucoup de nuances en plus, en tout cas pas assez, 
selon moi. Elle est certes progressive, mais on a le volume requis avec une bouteille de 75 cl,
et il faut toujours se méfier avec ce genre de bouteille !!!
La levure est une veine classique de brune double.
Lalcool soutient bien la bière mais na pas de complexité à travailler.
La finale se déroule sur une ambiance un peu rétro dune brune double de bon aloi qui serait
la parente dune cousine exotique sur le café et lanis. Bref, on est entre deux eaux et on ne sait
se fixer.
Conclusion : le problème de cette bière est dêtre restée sur une double, alors quune christmas
devrait passer à une quadruple (ou à tout le moins être une double à très fort caractère).
Ici ni le degré dalcool ni la complexité ne lont permis, mais elle reste une très honnête double.

33 cl bottle from Bieropholie, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. BB 23/09/10. 
App.:  Very deep brown-mahogany with a decent fluffy light tan foam.
  
Aroma:  Very rich, malty and SWEET with great gooey gobs of brown sugar, molasses, rich dark dried fruits stewed together, orange peel, some warm spices, an odd candle wax note (second beer with this...maybe my nose is defective), some cherries, dried glaceed fruits, a touch of brightness; a very festive Dubbel.
  
Palate:  Medium-full body, big, round effervescence that causes my cheeks to puff out.
  
Flav.:  Follows the nose with more gooey, dripping sweet malts, fruitiness, molasses and brown sugar, a fair bit of orange-citrus zip, that odd waxy note, some spices, so sweet and sticky; intensely sweet with nice rich malts and some warming alcohol in the finish.

I think I have a cavity.  And diabetes.

Pours a near-black body with a dense, pillowy off white head. Nose is immediate and intense; raisins, succade and candy sugar, with hints of port wine. Very Christmasy aromas floating around, and the taste backs up the promise: initial palate is smooth and filled with raisins and licorice. Hints of cinnamon and/or cardamom, cant really tell which is most to the front. Candy sugar coming towards the end, and vague, dry hop notes back up the finish. Complex stuff. Bocq Christmas is a tad bit sweet - even for a Christmas brew - particularly the licorice notes which sometimes waver into the land of succade and straight molasses. Alcohol is well hidden, with a warming feeling that comes gradually. A plus for the extremely seasonal feel, a minus for the relatively low drinkability, a result of both the overwhelming sweetness and the complexity of seasonal spice. As the bottle becomes empty my faint nausea grows, and I am forced to conclude that this is far too sweet for me.

Doesnt necessarily stand out for the style but quite enjoyable nonetheless.

My Bottom Line:
Cherry liqueur, chocolate malt and bready yeast are propelled by expansive effervescence in this pleasant Belgian Strong Ale.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A slice of foam covers the dark brown with reddish highlights.
-The finish is rather shortlived.
-This might be a tad rough around the edges, yet it remains a most satisfying Kerstbier.
-Spicy hops are relatively tame in the finish.

Whole range or tastes - I got something bacony at first, but theres also a zingy spicy component accompanying the most satisfying rich malty body. Soft richly-roasted malt finish. Alcohol present, but welcome. Big up the boys at Bocq!

Rerate of (6-4-7-3-12=3.2)
500ml bottle.
Different tongues detected different tastes. In theory theres salt, licorice and aniseed, but all I got was bananas. (Tasted with Tranquility.) Dry and crisp, but still bananas. Again, too strong for a sauna beer - better to savour.

Brown color with a nice white head.
Complex aromas with malt, roasted, caramel, spice and yeast.
In the palate i found malt, toffee, spice and a godd bitterness.

Small bottle. Dark clear colour with a nice white head. Rich aroma of  coriander and liquorice. Thick roasted malty flavour, the alcohol is bery much to be tasted too. Great mouthfeel. Nice aftertaste. Plenty of Christmas here!
Bottle. Clear dark amber colour with a huge light brownish head. Rich aroma and taste of malts, fruits and spice. Nice beer. Good palate.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2007 Bottle from the Rake. Lovely black cherry colour with a faint off white head. Nose of roasted malts - reminds me of Guiness. Much like a stout. Taste of coffee with roasted malts and dark berries to compliment. Its like a burnt fruitcake. Oddly appealing. Good stuff.
Bottle. Pours dark reddish brown with a thick beige head. Sweet candylike malt aroma with yeast and spices. Smooth mouthfeel but the sweetness is sticky and annoying.
Pours dark brown reddish with a thick tan head. Yeasty, spicy and peppery aroma. Flavor starts with strong peppery tones and brown sugar, ends with dry, alcoholic and spicy aftertaste.

330 ml bottle. Dark reddish brown and crystal clear. Tall fluffy head with big bubbles. Sourish salty mineral aroma. A bit soapy. More salt in the initial flavour. Balanced sweetness. In between other Belgian beers. A little dry and some retaining sweetness, but overall quite dry except because of the saltiness. Subdued hops. Disappointing complexity. Lacks a bit as it is not particularly exciting.

33 cL bottle. Very sweet aroma with a slight acidity, some dried fruits. Stiff tan foam leaving a rim on the glass; marginally hazy brown with orange tones. Very long bitter aftertaste. This and the feel of the foam on the lip is great. Quite good beer.
On draught. deep brownish red colour. Small head. Lots of spice; coriander, cinnamon, candid fruits. Its like drinking an xmas pud. Bit to rich for my palate.

<Bottle at home>
Dark brown with long lasting head. Aroma is sweet tofee with some spicy pepper like notes. The taste is abit too sweet for me, but the palate is just lovely. Creamy texture and lively carbonation and a long lasting, somehow hot finish.
Nice littel christmas beer found it on ISO-supermarket.Smells as yeast and tast like brown bred.nice mahony colour and a littel head.

0.75 l bottle. Reddish brown color with creamy tan head. Malty, sweet, caramelly, parfumy and candy-like aroma with licorice, chocolade and some tart fruitiness. Malty and caramelly flavor with some fruitiness and spices. Too sweet.
On tap at The White Horse, Parsons Green, 25th Nov. This has a great complex mix of fruit flavours with hints of wine and orange peel. Superb palate and aftertaste.

Bottled.
Amber with a beige head.
Citrus and pomerance in both aroma and flavour. A bit too spiced up for me.

Bottle @ Kerstbierfestival 2006 in Essen, BE. Dark red brown color with a average off-white head. Aroma of roasted malt, anis and spices. Flavor is heavy sweet , moderate bitter with a long duration.  Finish is ligth alcoholic. (A like Corsedonk Christmas, Best Christmas Wishes)

(Bottle BB 14/09/08) Anise, licorice and spicy aroma. Red brown colour, slightly hazy and brownish, average size, very slightly lasting head with good lacing. Sweet, malty, anise, fruity and licorice flavour. Lively carbonated, warming (alcohol does not taste) and medium to full-bodied palate. Excellent, tasty brew! 16/11/06

[bottle] Good looking beer. Malt, spices and loads of fruits and other yeasty things makes this beer a fine belgian. The spicyness is mostly coriander, pepper and suchlike. There isnt much to ramble on, just a plain and well-balanced beer thats miles away from some of the more cloyingly sweet belgian brews.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2010 Dark red colour. Intense aroma of spice and dried fruits coupled with whiskey like maltiness. Texture is very smooth and oily with light carbonation on the tongue. Flavour is full of sweet, dark dried fruits and malts.

Biggish offwhite head. Dark red translucent body. Harmonic spicy banana licorice aroma. Sweet, harmonic spicy banana licorice taste with cinnamon notes. Bitter licorice finish. Dry licorice taste lingers. Very good! Complex and powerful, but still easily drinkable. (0.75l bottle.)

Bottle from Systembolaget. A blood red beer with a rampageous head that thinned out but left sticky lacing. Smell of sweet candy, aniseed and orange. Peppary and distinct corriander top notes, quite sweet with low bitterness. A little funk in there too. Good BSA with complex spice character - but doesnt particular remind me of Christmas.
33 cL bottle. Pours a clear dark amber colour. Sweet smell of hops. Sweet taste wih malt, fruit and spice notes. Complex taste that gives the impression of drinking a vegetable. Not my kind of beer.
Quite similar to Corsendunk Christmas ale, but a little bit sweeter finish. Huge coplex spicy taste, but not at all overdone.
Bottled. Reddish dark brown coloured with a medium sized head. Sweet and malty with notes of anis and coriander. A bit too high carbonated.

330ml compact bottle picked up at Systembolaget and enjoyed at the hotel room. Quite nice aroma of pine and malt from an attractive deep brown gown. Taste of coriander, sweet anise and (too much) candy sweetness. Smooth, fizzy and smokey. Full bodied (02.12.2006).

Bottle: Deep clear red colour, with a nice thick creamy head.
Aroma is malty,toffee,citrus and a bit flowery in the end.
Flavor is smouth and round fruitynes, lots of malt and sprakling on the tung.Citrus bitter finish. Medium body, medium finish.
 Nice!!
Bottle. Dark, good head. Big aroma of orange rinds and detergent. Malty and yeasty. Tricky beer. Good though.

Draught @ Bishops Arms, Malmö. Pours a clear dark amber colour with a longlasting two finger thick off-white head. Sweet malty, spicy and slightly yeasty aroma. Sweet malty fruity and spicy flavor. Dry spicy finish.
Bottle 75 cl (2005 edition). Dark brown colour, long lasting head. Aroma of fruit and yeast. Not as much alcohol flavour as the "usual" belgian christmas ales.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2007 (Draught at White Horse, Parsons Green, London, 25 Nov. Rerate: bottle 8 Jan 2007) Dark brown colour with ruby notes, frothy beige head. Fruity nose with notes of yeast, dried fruit, toffee, fudge, coriander, cinnamon and an hint of cherries in brandy. Fruity, yeasty taste with dried fruit, apricots and a spicy bitterness in the finish. Notes of cardamom and cinnamon. Nice and spicy.
Bottle 33 cl. Pours with thin head. I find it too sweet. Malty, slightly yeasty with taste of marcipan and fruit.
A Sim Rate (on tap at The White Horse): Raspberry wine aroma. Sweet but not too sweet. Bittersweet flavour. Slightly creamy. Decent palate. Dark chocolate aftertaste.
Bottle at Ølbaren. Dark red/brown - white head. High malty, bread, berries, licorice, chokolate. Medium carbonation.
Red/amber color, offwhite quite quickly disappearing head. Fruity sourish aroma, some nuts and was there strwberry notes? Quite weak flavor to be this strong. A bit fruity and with some bitterness.
Red to amber colour. A winous sweet aroma. Much red fruits. Flavor is sweet malty, yeasty and spicy.
(33 cl bottle) Spicy, malty and yeasty smell. Shady red color. Lots of ginger bread. Spicy taste. Thin mouthfeel.
Pours red/brown. Spicy aroma with nutmeg and white pepper. Plums and a bit sour. Sweet and stale flavour with light spices and green herbs. Light syrupy with hints of honey. Small to medium body.

Bottle 0,75l. Deep brown coloured. Light brown creamy head leaving patterns inside the glass. Rich spicy aroma. Complex flavour with undertones of dark fruits. The lasting aftertaste is dominated by malt. More a winter-warmer than a Christmas beer.

Bottle 0,75l. Wow! Salmiak beer! This contains really weird ingredients like anis, salt (!) and liqurice. This is clear in the taste. Deep ruby, small head. When swallowing the salt really lingers in your mouth. Excellent.

Bottled. Clear brownish amber colour. Rish belgian-style white head. The aroma is dominated by nutmeg with touchesall-spice, toffee and yeast. Spicy flavour of nutmeg, cloves, fudge, sweat and banana. Spices, nuts and white chocolate in the finish
UPDATED: NOV 20, 2006 Dark amber with an off-white head. Spicy, hoppy with some yeast notes. Full bodied with  a sour aftertaste. Too much carbonation !

Aroma: honey, cookies, mango, hops, liquoriceroot (very obvious before I had even read the ingredients), BELGIAN, invert sugar(?).  Appearance: deep red, slightly orange. Warm, yellowy beigetinted white foam.  Flavor: Liquorice, sweet-bitter, very unusual, vaguely metallic, full-bodied, hoppy and malty afterbitterness, cornsugar?, "Duvel meets malt & liquorice", herbalesque bitterness (like wormwood).  Palate: full-bodied, good level of co2!, some slimyness.  A classic?

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2006 Bottle. Clear red-brown body. Big offwhite head. Delicious aromas of malts and cream-caramel along with some fresh and acidic fruity notes. Taste is toasted malts, dried and acidic fruits, spices and warming alcohol. Medium bodied. Lingering dry and malty finish. Yum... a perfect winter-warmer!
bottle. dark amber color. farty sweet aroma. very xmasy. dark fruits. lots of sweet.

A lot of different berries and fruits in the spicy aroma, but the most obvious must be raspberry and matured plums. The taste is mainly malts, alcohol and matured fruits, which is followed by a nice hopping. The aftertaste is with matured fruits, alcohol and hops again. Too typical belgian strong ale. However, I sense some christmas-like cinnamon in there. Good ale, but typical.
(Bottle)  Pours a burgundy body with a lasting large rocky beige head with good lacing.  Aroma of toffee, toasted malt, vinous, mustiness, raisin, and plums.  Flavor of raisins and toasted malt.
[Bottled as Regal Christmas Millennium 9.0% in January 2000] Dark brown, lively. Yeasty with funky blue cheese aroma. Like a French Bière de garde, but with more power.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2006 Bottled, 75cl. BB 070922. A beautiful deep reddish-brown color with some carbonation, and a huge, dense beige head. Nice lacings and almost no yeast sediments. The aroma is yeasty cellar-like, with caramel, candi-sugar, dried fruits and some spicyness. Flavor has caramel , candi-sugar, lots of dried fruits, some spices and alcohol. There is a bit sourness in it too. A little sticky on the palate, with a full body and a lovely, sweet finish with some bitterness. Goes well with typical Norwegian turkey- or pork-based Christmas dinners. (060429)

Dark almost like a porter.Lovely full body without being overpowering. Some maltiness and traces of fruit.I sometimes find Belgian strong ales an aquired taste-it took a matter of seconds to aquire the taste for this one. An excellent beer.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2010 Dark brown colour, small off-white head. and some light carbonation. Deep caramel malty aroma, light yeasty with some roasted hints. Sweet palate, full creamy body. Finish is light bitter, some caramel again with some notes of suggar and malts. Sweet, but not bad.

Got to love the humour in the label. I missed downing these at Christmas after my wife surprised me with a boxed set. What a sweetheart. After trying a Gribousine DHiver and finding that worked well in the heat of this years subnormal autumn this one was the obvious next choice.   Into its own goblet, cool but not cold. Deep, ruby red in body (black off the light). Head surged up the glass and stabilised a dense, rocky beige and a good inch and a half thick. Clung firmly to the sides frosting over three quarters of the glass as I sipped.   Mixture of berries, stone-fruits and Black sambuca in the aroma. Lightly zesty with a pleasant tickle of aniseed and alcohol.   Prickly on the front of the tongue; sweet, vinous and very smooth through into the swallow. Strong flavours of plums, blackberries and a tang of cranberries; drying dark malts and a light balancing touch of liquorice, burnt wood and peppery spice. Fills the mouth well; very tight in flavour on the palate with a woody, dry and warming finish that only shows a little of the huge alcohol.   Another well-crafted and seamless brew from Du Bocq. Have to save a few bottles for this years silly season.  Enjoyable!!! (33cL, 05/09/07)
Malt hop aroma with spice. Red brown colear colour with fair head and lacing. Malt hop flavour with spice. Fizzy yet smooth palate.
1 Mar 06 - Lovely spicy apricot aroma.  Dark brown-red colour, good head retention and suds lacing.  Rich fruit spiritous big spicy malt flavours.  Spicy hop malt finish but perhaps is a bit thin.

75 cl bottle. Pours chestnut brown with a rich off-white head. The aroma is fruity caramel with some yeastiness. Sweet caramel flavours with liquorice and fruits, good offsetting bitterness, dry finish. Good carbonation. A very pleasant Christmas beer.

750 ml gave a nice pop when I pulled the cork. Pour a dark red/brown with tons of head. Spices filled the nose. had a good mix of malt and spice. A good strong beer without feeling too heavy. Thin a bubbly like drinking champagne. A nice holiday treat.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2007 Bottle.
Hazy copper color, small off-white head.
Very belgian aroma and flavor of sweet malts, yeast, spices, and a hint of sherry, with emphasis on the malt and spices.
Medium body. Alcohol quite well hidden.
Nice, and very christmassy too.

Re-rate dec 27, 2006:
Apparently, I had forgotten Id already rated this one. Ah well, re-rates can be quite interesting too. Here goes:

Bottled 2006.

Beautiful, hazy copper color, with small, bubby beige head. Some yeast sediment in bottom of bottle.
Dryish aroma of molasses, yeast, and hops, with a hint of alcohol sweetness.
Ditto for flavor, albeit somewhat sweeter than aroma. Bitterish aftertaste.
Medium body, clean mouthfeel, rather heavy carbonation.

App:4; Aro:6; Fla:6; Pal:2.

So, not quite as pleasing this time around. I espcially found the heavy carbonation a bit tiring. Perhaps this bottle wouldve needed to mature a bit longer...

This deep red Belgian Ale has a lot going for it! Malty, fruity, and spicy all at once (sweet raisins, licorice). Nice high carbonation. However, the hops in the dry finish are not worthy of a true top rating (4+). Nonetheless, I really like this stuff!
Bottled. Hazy dark Brown, rich white head. The aroma is sweet and malty. The flavor consists of roasted hops with a sweet after taste.

750  ml corked bottle. Brown colour. Yeasty, malty and spicy flavour. Taste 2004 and 2005 at the same time.
The beer is best when it have been stored a while.

Bottled. Reddish amber colour, big off white head. Sweet alcohol, caramel and weak malts and rye in aroma. Flavour is sweet caramellish malts with some soapish hints. Weak plum with hops in finish. Semi-oily palate. Lovely label on the bottle...
Very dark amber, dark brown coloured brew. Very nice smooth flavor. Chocolate and brown sugar, with a bit bitterness. Well balanced, nice christmas ale enjoyed on christmas.

Brown cola like body with a tan coloured head. Smooth flavour, a little thin for an 8%, Rich flavour, dark chocolate and then cocoa thinness, burnt brown sugar and thin caramel.
Head almost lasted, and then also some lace.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2006 Veyr nice, cloudy, and orange,. The last of the session. And a good one to enjy in Christmas. I wanted to keep them for after Christmas, but I guess they were too many to carry to Home with me.
Afine christmas ale. Well, the head is gone quickly. Amber color. Good flavor, mint and laqurice. A bit thin.
Bottle. Light brown head. Dark red brown body. Aroma of oranges. Corander liqorice flavor.
not bad. not great too. spicy, fruity aroma. smells better than it tastes. spicy, malty. metallic taste and aroma disappears over time.

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2013 Bottle at DØE tasting. Medium+ sweet, dark fruit, brown sugar, well balanced.
---
Draught, at The Rover.
Dark brown with a beige head. Aroma moderate to heavy malty, moderate hoppy (roasted, spicy). Flavor moderate sweet and bitter. Medium body, oily, flat carbonated. Missing character (hops and carbonation). 29-11-2005 8-4-6-3-12 total 3,3.

Pours dark brown reddish with a thick tan head. Yeasty, spicy and peppery aroma. Dusty but still rather sticky. Malty and spicy flavor with roasted notes. Dark fruit, caramel and brown sugar also. Quite sweet with a heavy citrusy and spicy finish. A good beer without beeing extraordinary!

Beige foamy full lasting head. Dark brown, almost black color. Aroma is fruity with floral, spicy, liquorice, banana, apricots notes. Flavor is initially balanced turning soon sweet with fruity (banana, raisins), vanilla and light spicy notes, ending in a long fruity finish. Medium to full bodied.

Vintage 2003. Very nice aroma, with notes of prunes, dried dark fruits, vanilla and a touch of alcohol. Dark reddish body with a small tan head. Sweet and fruity flavor, with notes of prunes, quite well balanced.
33 cl bottle. Dark brown colour with a nice white head. Sweet aroma with spicy notes. Some roasted flavour that ends very bitter and dry, in somewhat unpleasant way.

This pours a clear, rich brown body with a slight reddish highlighting and a healthy tan head.  The aroma is caramel malt filled with alcohol and sweet spices.  Light bodied but bubbly in the mouth, it has a sweet malty taste with dark dried fruits, candy sugar, some hot spices, and a definite alcoholic bite.  Its got a warm, sticky, bittersweet finish and an alcohol afterburn.  Not bad.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.belgianshop.com/>The Belgian Shop<font size=-1>

Bottled.
Clear red brown coloured with a solid and lacing off white head.
Nice spicy aroma with lots of dried fruits and some malty sweetness.
Sweet flavour of dried fruits, spices, liquorice and dark bread.
Slightly bitter finish.
Palate is a bit thin.

(Bottle 75 cl) My version had 9% ABV. Black - not brown - pitch black licorice-like appearance, brownish frothy head. . Almost tar... Extremely rich and full-bodied. Spicy almost peppery notes with lots of burned malt. Some hoppines in the finish. Gee what a solid, potent brew. 191297

Dark Copperish brown with a slight head.  I smell some iron, oak, and fruit.  The flavor is a shimmering bitterness receding back on the tongue.  Some lingering bitternish, and the alcohol is well masked.  Palate is very pleasant, with round carbonated esters.  A very nice beer with food.

Dense and creamy foam, much persistent. Dark brown color, loads and lightly veiled. Loaded and decided scent, much alcoholic and flowery. Complex. Full bodied, determined taste whit liquorice and licorice notes. Moderately bitter and persistent.

Deep brown-red.  Nose some chocolate and cherries, bit spicy, slight hint of cardboard.  Fruity up front, gets a bit nutty and toasty.  Yeasty, somewhat vinous, vaguely spicy.  Bit metallic at the end.

Bottled in 1996 and consumed at Heeren Van Liedekercke (near Brussels). This dark brown ale poured with a nice tan head, eliciting a malty aroma. The flavor was very mellow and port-like. There was much less alcohol taste than anticipated, perhaps because of the age of the beer. It went well with the excellent beef stew ordered here.

Bottled: Burgundy coloured. Clear. Fluffy beige head. Spices, sweets and fruits in the aroma. Some caramel, spices and malt in the flavour. Ends on sweet and malty note. Is thin to medium bodied. Nothing to run for.
Bottle. Metallic aroma with brown sugar notes. Dark brown colour, big unstable head. Roasted start, malty middle, bitter dry finish, sweet malty aftertaste. Substantial body, almost swelling.

75 cl bottle, bbe 14th Oct 06. Brown-red with a rich head. The base of the odour are dark malts, abundantly built upon by mint-like aroma. Rounded and metallic flavour with a pronounced hoppy bitter aftertaste.

Pours dark brown reddish with a thick tan head. Yeasty, spicy and peppery aroma. Dusty but still rather sticky. Malty and spicy flavor with roasted notes. Dark fruit, caramel and brown sugar also. Quite sweet with a heavy citrusy and spicy finish. A good beer without beeing extraordinary!

A very dark Ruby color with a massive fine beige head. Very malty with an odd hard to pin down "plasticy"/ "cottage cheese" scent. Sweet but thin, has a metallic taste that is very detracting. It is still a bit cold, I will set this one aside for a few to see if warming improves the taste. 15 mins later.....much improved in flavor, the plastic funky taste is gone, mostly malt and a mild peppery taste. It was nasty and has improved, but only to average.

Dark red color, nice lasting beige head. Spicy and peppery aroma, alcohol covered totally. Mild toffee comes up later. Medium to full bodied, alcohol comes up strongly in flavor. Flavor starts with strong peppery tones and brown sugar, ends with dry, alcoholic and spicy aftertaste. Aroma is slightly thin and flavor has little too much alcohol, otherwise excellent brew.
Reddish brown colour with a solid beige head. Fruity sweet aroma with some alcohol. Flavor is malty and fruity with some bitterness in the finish.
Brown. Solid head. Metallic aroma. Earthy, malty, bitter, fruity flavor. Dry finish. Nice winter warmer. Soft mouthfeel.

Bottle at Plan B. Cph. Dk. Thanks to Martin and Niels!!! Dark red-brown color and a small head. Light metallic fruity sweet aroma and  sweet caramel bitter taste. Medium to full body and a bitter sweet finish.

Deep ruby red colour. Spicy aroma, with herbal and medicinal notes. Dried fruit, currants, candy sugar and licorice in the flavour. Some bitterness. Rich, but not too sweet. Full mouthfeel. A nice Christmas beer. Bottled at the Beer Circus, Croydon.

Sweet malty aroma, light spice, rootbeer, fruity hops. Sugary with some caramel. Deep ruby brown clear with huge foamy light tan lacing head. Medium heavy watery body with medium-high carbonation. Alcohol burn. Starts medium sweet, with brown sugar, ginger, and other spice. Mild saltiness. Some alcoholic warming but more of a carbonic tang. Good fruity hops, with drying light bitter in the finsih. Some sweetness and malt hangs around the whole time, and after is light bitter sweet nutty flavor. A good Christmas ale, sweet but well balanced with dry hops. A bit watery, though.
Bottled.  A spicy, alcoholic, vinuous aroma with hints of raisins.  Dark brown beer with a nice tan head.  The taste is spicy, sugary sweet and also a bit milky.  Very tasty.
Bottle. A wonderful little Christmas ale. Smooth licoricey, dark fruit flavours, with some nice spicy coriander. Very nice and soft, tastes Christmasy.
Big chocolate, caramel, berry and spice in aroma. Light brown with a tan head. Sweet caramel and banana, slight liquorice there too. Medium-full smooth. Great

Bottled (75cl) (BB 04/2006)
Clear deep red, huge cloudy brown head. Strong aroma of malts and leather. Smooth, carbonated palate. Loads of licorice, malts and salt. Balanced, warming palate, salty aftertaste.
Bottle at the Beer Circus, Croydon, London.. Spicy dark, chocolately beer. Herbal and some bitterness.
UPDATED: NOV 27, 2007 Bottle  Fizzy, light brown, fully diminishing head.  Clear, brown body.  Grapefruit aroma.  Heavily bitter initial flavour and finish (long-lasting). Medium bodied.
Bottle. Dark brown with nice, long lasting head. Sweet, spicy, light liqourice and metal notes. Smooth, medium body. Nice.

Mahogany coloured, opaque, thin and few persistent head. Very elegant aroma, spicy and fruity: candy cherry and "cappuccino" notes. Discreet body, licorice and caramel flavours, alcohol was not so evident, slightly carbonated. Well balanced hop.

Bottled. Dark cherry red coloured body with a fine medium sized beige head. Strong sweet malt aroma. Flavour is dominated by malts, toffee and caramel and spiced soaked Christmas fruit. Alcohol is slightly noticeable on the palate but not offensively so.

nice winterbeer,well presented.
Full bodied beer for cold winters, spicy, malty, and a nice sweet finish.
Sweet toffee, caramel and malt in the aroma. low carbonation, malt and burned chocolate in flavour. Dark amber colour, low head. Mild palate and finish of brown sugar and candis.
Brown colored with a beige head. The taste is sweet malty, slight fruity and with notes of nuts.

(I deliberatly choose a very well-aged sample - well from the Du Bocq period, of course. This kind of beer usually benefits from it). Nearly red amber, slight yeast specks; virtually no head. Sweet caramel & portwine nose, fruity. Taste of good vintage port, fruity, slightly nutty. No noxious oxydation. Sweetness just in check, vinous. Mellow, alcoholic mouthfeel, like a vintage fortified wine again. Not really overly heavy-bodied. Excellent vinous beer. I might have been prejudiced about the age factor, IMO I was vindicated by the result. I can only recommend opening this only quite aged - with possible spectacular results. From memory, the younger versions are way too sweet, with an unpleasant scorched bitterness.

Yeasty, malty-sweetish and fruity aroma with some hints of pepper or other spices. Quite decent. Cloudy, dark brown coloured with a thin, lasting and off-white head. Yeasty, sweetish-roasted malty taste (toffee) with some spices (pepper again?) and fruits (grapefruit). More bitter in the middle and in the finish. Dry and bitterness in the end. Very decent brew.

A nice dark-red hue with a big, foamy tan head.  It has a sweet spicy (coriander), yeasty aroma that is very pleasant.  Somewhat metallic aftertaste. The mouthfeel is moderate at best with a good malty middle.  Chimay-like flavor.  Nice but the finish is a little off.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2008 Jan, 2004  Bottle Conditioned. From Bottles, London. BBE Nov 04.  Dark reddish brown with big head. Yeast, underarm, black pepper aroma. Malty. Some sweetness. Surprisingly thinnish body for strength. Pepper in flavour. Yeast. Acceptable, but not that interesting. [2.8]
Jan, 2008 Draught at Delirium, Brussels. Hmm - go to the bar with the worlds biggest selection of beers, and end up buying a beer Ive had before!  Alcohol, sherry, Christmas cake. Rum soaked raisins. Old Jamaica. Licorice, mint, rosemary. Quite wonderful. Brown sugar. Sweet and alcoholic. [3.5]
(3 liter bottle) Nice off white head, good lacing. very balanced aroma, taste. A very good beer for a celebration occasion!!

The best thing about this beer was the wonderful appearance and the inviting aroma.  It lost alot in the other catagories.  Aroma was nice,with hints of yeast malt and toffee.  Appearance was very good with a large creamy tan head on a ruby / mahogany beer.  Flavor was balanced but uninspired.  yes malt, sweetness in initial and dry at the finish.  Not bad but there are better out there.  Keep looking.
A deep red beer with a fantastic head. The aroma is nice; sweet malty with a hint of sourness. The flvaor is very sweet fruity. It doesn't remind me of Christmas but it is a fine Belgium Ale.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2009 (Bottled, 0.75l) Hazy orangeish brown color with medium, beige head. Quite spicy, fruity and bitter-hoppy aroma with toffee hints. Sweetish-malty, nicely spicy, toffee flavor with a strong anise finish. Smooth, medium to full-bodied, slightly sugary-sticky and wineous, quite bitter palate with some alcohol and foamy carbonation. A very enjoyable, full-bodied and spicy Belgian christmas ale - like a mixture of Orval and Westmalle Dubbel. Tastes great even at room temp. (0.33l bottle) Quite sweet, no Orval sourness, simpler than a big bottle. Would score 3.7.

Bottle-conditioned, Best before end 1999. Cloudy brown color, no head, probably because of its age. Extremely alcoholic nose, wine-like. Sweet taste, very alcoholic, quite complex. Spicy, malty, all together. Not a starter though.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2011 Re-rate: Bottled, Regal X-Mas, from my parents cellar, approx. 8 years old. Very dark brown colored, small brown head. Very strong malty nose, lots of chocolate, fruit, caramel, impressive. Flavor has lots of liquorice, in between sweet and bitter, balanced. Very thick mouthfeel. Im impressed, this kind of complexity is almost exclusively found at ABVs above 10%. Still, i have no clue what a fresh version would taste like.
Previous rating (3.8):19-04-2003 (BB 09-1999). Dark brown, no head. Malty, port-like aroma with some liquorice. Strong port-like flavour, like an aged (>5 years) Chimay Bleu. Not as balanced though. Not an everyday beer, but very nice on occasion.
Malty aroma with pepper and grapes. Malty, prickly flavor with licorice, grapes and some fairly well hidden alcohol. Medium bodied. Very well made beer, warming and some complexity.
Deep, deep purple color; Big milkshake head; tart toffee nose. Very mild. Slight grapey maltiness. Not a ton of depth. Like a weak Chimay GR.
Clear mahogany with small tan head.  Aroma is sweet bubblegum, caramel, somewhat fruity.  Taste is pretty bland -- peppery, not much else.  Hint of bubblegum, has a dry finish.  Disappointing.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2003 Deep copper brown.  Zero foam.  Yeast laden aroma.  Underlying notes of ginger, toasted bread, mint, port wine, fruit cake, and wood.  Lovely mouthfeel with with lots of fluffiness, which is yielded by a wonderful job of the bottle conditioning.  Huge malt notes of crystal and a trace of peatiness.  Very unique and delicious flavors compliment the sweet malts ingeniously with spruce, juicy fruit gum, herbal traits, and pepper.  Long malty finish with a perfect touch of numbing spice.  Very Christmasy and just what I was seeking in this spicy Bruin style.

text: UPDATED: MAY 2, 2005 750 ml corked bottle conditioned, cool label! Brown colour, slightly hazy, good initial head but not lingering, lovely spicy aroma, yeasty, malty and spicy flavour - a real treat for the Christmas table.
Light amber cloured beerwith a big, off white head. The aroma is malt, slightly roasted and somewhat perfumy. The taste is malt with a hint of caramel and flower. Slightly bitter finish.
